text1: Higher intensity and/or frequency of seasonal precipitation intensity
text2:
If high intensity rainfall has been an issue already, then:
  • Stormwater design standard may no longer be adequate for new construction.
  • May need to increase capacity of existing drainage infrastructure or augment with retention ponds.
  • Possible reduced seasonal water quality.
  • Possibility of more frequent combined sewer overflows
  • Possible increased stream bank erosion

condition: ((!rule_snow && ((prec_djf_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_djf_iamean_smean_hist) > prec_djf_iastddev_smean_hist) || (((prec_mam_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_mam_iamean_smean_hist) > prec_mam_iastddev_smean_hist) || (((prec_jja_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_jja_iamean_smean_hist) > prec_jja_iastddev_smean_hist) || (((prec_son_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_son_iamean_smean_hist) > prec_son_iastddev_smean_hist))
text1: Higher intensity and/or frequency of rainfall events
text2:
• Consider impact on drainage appliances (may exceed design capacity)
  • Consider impact to road safety due to ponding and hydroplaning.
  • Road crest design may require modification to shed water more quickly.
  • Increased risk of flooding and debris flow
comment: same as 1a-i-hydro but only djf if not a snow basin.

text2: • Intense rainfall event may occur when soils are already saturated

Assess storm water drainage systems (urban, rural and agricultural) with respect to new precipitation loads:
  • Consider impact of Total Impervious Area (TIA).
  • Assess need for dikes and stormwater retention ponds.
  • Re-examine development guidelines.
  • Re-examine landscape development guidelines.
  • Assess agricultural drainage network (requires collaboration with landowners, local governments, FNs).
Consider flood adaptation strategies:
  • Managed retreat and abandonment.
  • Optionts for crop production on frequently flooded land.
  • Potential loss of arable land.
Possible impact on parks:
  • Possible reduction of recreation services due to field closures may require Parks & Rec services to change or adjust program schedules.
  • Natural area parks with streams & creeks may flood requiring greater local budget to manage natural areas.
Assess and develop emergency management response plan:
  • Identify key community assets, e.g. hospitals, schools that could be vulnerable to flooding.
• Consider effects on habitat.

condition: ((((prec_mam_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_mam_iamean_smean_hist) > prec_mam_iastddev_smean_hist) || (((prec_jja_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_jja_iamean_smean_hist) > prec_jja_iastddev_smean_hist) || (((prec_son_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_son_iamean_smean_hist) > prec_son_iastddev_smean_hist))
text1: Possibility of increase in extreme rainfall events
text2:
• Possible increase in soil erosion.
  • Possible crop damage.

text1: Possibility of increase in extreme rainfall events
text2: • Potential disruption to pollination and planting.

text1: Possibility of increase in extreme rainfall events
text2: • Potential disruption/prevention of harvesting..

text1: Possibility of increase in extreme rainfall events
text2: • Possible increase in nutrient and input leaching.

• If flooding is a current issue, then there may be an increase in frequency and magnitude.
  • Consider that stormwater design standard may no longer be adequate for new construction.
  • May need to increase capacity of existing drainage infrastructure or augment with retention ponds.
  • Reduced seasonal water quality is likely.
  • More frequent combined sewer overflows.
  • Increased likelihood of stream bank erosion.
  • Probable reduced level of service for flood protection.

text1: Possibility of increase in extreme rainfall events
text2:
• Review emergency management planning and response in consideration of expected changes and increased variability.
  • Consider agricultural impacts in flood management responses.

text1: Possible increase in chance of flow barrier for returning salmon
text2:
Plan for possible increase in incidence of:
  • Spawning failure.
  • Forgone harvest.
  • Fisheries closures.
  • Conflicts among users.
  • Species at risk concerns.
  • Jurisdictional issues in management response.

Possible washout of spawning habitat:
  • Habitat damage â€“ loss of spawning habitat and stream bottom changes.
  • Woody debris distribution.
• For coastal watersheds, sea level rise combined with increased river flows will exacerbate coastal and delta flood risk.

• Increased risk of stream and river flooding.
  • Consider implications for flood hazard management.
  • Consider increased strain on dikes and other flood protection infrastructure by more frequent, higher river flows
  • Potential for increased sediment accumulation in stream and river beds which reduces channel capacity and can result in potential impacts on bridge stability.
  • Possible that erosion may increase, consider impacts on property and habitat.

• Potential for increased sediment accumulation in stream and river beds.
  • Possible that erosion may increase, consider impacts on habitat.

condition: (((prec_son_iamean_smean_e25p > 0) && (prec_mam_iamean_smean_e25p > 0)) || (((prec_djf_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_djf_iamean_smean_hist > prec_djf_iastddev_smean_hist) || ((prec_mam_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_mam_iamean_smean_hist > prec_mam_iastddev_smean_hist) || ((prec_jja_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_jja_iamean_smean_hist > prec_jja_iastddev_smean_hist) || ((prec_son_iamean_smean_e25p / 100) * prec_son_iamean_smean_hist > prec_son_iastddev_smean_hist)))
text2:
Possible on-farm agriculture implications:
  • Consider options for managing excess water on farm. (Regional infrastructure/ditch/drainage coordination may be required to enable on-farm drainage to work.)

• Consider adjusting planting schedules.
  • Potential negative impacts on pollination success.
• Consider adjusting harvesting schedules.

• Consider nutrient/input runoff and impacts on water quality.
  • Coordinate regional ditch, drainage and diking system to manage possible excess water.
  • Assess local land use, steep slope soil composition; consider slope hazards.
  • Consider additional local studies and geotechnical analysis.
  • Consider a risk assessment to understand liability (e.g.: slope failure, falling trees) for local government.

text1: Sea level rise and possible increase in storm surges
text2: • For coastal watersheds, sea level rise combined with increased river flows will exacerbate coastal / delta flood risk.

text1: Sea level rise and possible increase in storm surges
text2:
• May require new design guidelines for Flood Control Levels (FCLs) and infrastructure.
  • Increased communication & collaboration between Engineering and Planning departments.

text1: Sea level rise and possible increase in storm surges
text2: • Farmland in coastal / delta areas may be affected.

text1: Possible reduced summer stream flow and lower ground water table
text2:
• Consider concerns for meeting local water demand.
  • May need to assess and increase water storage capacity.
  • Possible lower summer and early fall stream flow.
  • Possible longer periods of low flows.

• Consider increased demand for storage reservoirs
  • Consider increase in water conservation/demand management/watering restrictions.
  • Consider water metering to evaluate consumption levels.

text1: Increased possibility of drought or increased salinity of wetlands
text2: • May affect groundwater quality.

• Consider effects on habitat.
  • Can be combined with winter/spring runoff indicators to recommend need for irrigation water storage requirements.

Possible decrease in soil moisture:
  • Consider options for managing soil moisture, irrigation infrastructure.

text1: Increased possibility of drought or increased salinity of wetlands
text2:
Drought planning and management required:
  • Consider water quality in standing water sources used by livestock.

• Review drought management plans as defined by the water act modernization project.
  • Review landscape development guidelines; water conservation & water restrictions.
  • Plan for compact complete communities and adaptive urban design, e.g. Phoenix.
  • Possible loss of ecosystem goods and services in terms of the provision of drainage, cooling, recreation and water supply.
  • Fire suppression planning.
  • Water supply identification

text1: Freshet advance and dry season extends  on order of several days per decade
text2:
Advance of freshet:
  • Possible longer dry period.
  • Reduced water supply.
  • Increased demand for storage reservoirs.
  • Stronger water use restrictions.

text1: Possible increase in fire season length
text2:
Possible increase in length of fire season:
  • Severity of fires might also increase.
  • Evaluate staffing and distribution of forest protection staff and resources.

text1: Shorter access season where winter access requires frozen roads
text2:
• length of winter logging season likely to decline.
  • Greater stockpiles of logs may be needed to keep mills working during freeze-up/break-up.

text1: Opportunities for facilitated migration of interior Douglas Fir, Western Larch  to the north; possible expansion of range of southerly temperate species
text2: • Consider planting more southerly temperate species depending on growing season/frosts in local context.

• May enable longer growing/production seasons for certain commodities.
  • Possible reduction in heating costs in cold season.

• Possible decline in lake productivity.
  • Salmon (juvenile) smolt migration timing possibly affected.

• Utilities and foundations might not need to be as deep; potentially less frost heaving on roads.
  • Consider implications for road maintenance program.
  • Consider further investigation of daily minimum temperatures.

text1: Projected summer or winter temperature change is larger than the standard deviation of historical interannual variability
text2:
• Species interactions are possibly disrupted.
  • Possible change in amount and timing of use of different parts of species' range (eg summer vs. winter areas).
  • Consider increasing invasion by exotic species (also expansion of range of impact of exotic species).
  • Possible changes in populations of pollinators; this has a ripple effect on biodiversity & agriculture.
  • Possible phenological changes.
  • Possible productivity changes.
  • Possible behaviour of species changes.
  • Possible species extinction/extirpation and/or hyperabundance.
  • Possible increase in incidence of human/wildlife conflict.
  • Possible change in winter migration patterns (location, timing); potentially, species will cease migrating.
  • Possible that more generalist species will be favored (decrease in biodiversity).
comment: Comparing ratio to 1 is same as inequality involving the two things you're dividing.

text1: Increase in frequency of occurrence of high temperatures
text2:
• Consider options for managing extreme heat and humidity:
    • Adjusting practices or technologies.
    • Changing crops.
  • Potential increase in ventilation costs or management intensity for dairy, poultry, greenhouse production.

text1: Asphalt performance and temperature-sensitive infrastructure components could be adversely affected
text2:
Temperature Increase:
  • Potential changes to road maintenance programs.
  • Potential changes to rehabilitation programs.
  • Potential changes to design parameters for new infrastructure.
  • See the PIEVC report for more case studies.
comment: Report doesn't exist anywhere; broken link.

text2:
Possible increase in heat waves:
  • Health impacts from lower air quality (e.g. in Lower mainland, Prince George)
  • Public heat stress may be an issue requiring cooling centres.

text1: Possible hydrologic regime transition: hybrid to rainfall dominant
text2:
Potential decline in late spring / summer flows imply possible water storage issues:
  • Loss of recreational use in reservoirs/streams.
  • Increased need for seasonal storage.

text1: Possible hydrologic regime transition: snowmelt to hybrid
text2:
Potential decline in late spring / summer flows imply possible water storage issues:
  • Loss of recreational use in reservoirs/streams.
  • Increased need for seasonal storage.

condition: ((temp_son_iamean_smean_hist + temp_son_iastddev_smean_hist) < 0) && ((temp_son_iamean_smean_hist + temp_son_iamean_smean_e25p + temp_son_iastddev_smean_hist) > 0) && ((temp_son_iamean_smean_hist + temp_son_iamean_smean_e25p - temp_son_iastddev_smean_hist) < 0) || ((temp_djf_iamean_smean_hist + temp_djf_iastddev_smean_hist) < 0) && ((temp_djf_iamean_smean_hist + temp_djf_iamean_smean_e25p + temp_djf_iastddev_smean_hist) > 0) && ((temp_djf_iamean_smean_hist + temp_djf_iamean_smean_e25p - temp_djf_iastddev_smean_hist) < 0) || ((temp_mam_iamean_smean_hist + temp_mam_iastddev_smean_hist) < 0) && ((temp_mam_iamean_smean_hist + temp_mam_iamean_smean_e25p + temp_mam_iastddev_smean_hist) > 0) && ((temp_mam_iamean_smean_hist + temp_mam_iamean_smean_e25p - temp_mam_iastddev_smean_hist) < 0)
text1: Likely increase in frequency of freeze-thaw cycles
text2:
• Possible increase in fatigue and degradation of infrastructure.
  • Consider further research into daily min-max temperature change.

category: Increase in Hot and Dry Conditions
text1: Increased possibility of water shortages at times of peak demand
text2:
Consider options including:
  • collaborative water management planning;
  • improved water conservation practices;
  • improved irrigation infrastructure;
  • improved water storage — regional infrastructure and on-site.

category: Increase in Hot and Dry Conditions
text2:
• Possible improved potential for crop productivity.
  • Consider risk of plant and livestock stress; requires management measures.

category: Increase in Hot and Dry Conditions
text1: Potential stress to resident and migrating fish and habitat
text2:
• Fish die-offs possible.
  • Consider reassessing habitat protection/availability (review standards/riparian guidelines, regulations).
  • Review recreational use of habitat
  • Anticipate conflict with other water users (hydro, agriculture).
  • Review conservation status of fish species/ecosystem.
  • Consider more complex management and trade-offs.
  • Possible conflict in species management.
  • Possible conflict in fisheries allocations

category: Increase in Hot and Dry Conditions
text1: Problems/barriers to migratory fish due to thermal stress on fish habitat
text2:
• Possible spawning failure.
  • Potential of declined harvest/cancellation of harvest.
  • Possible conflict in fisheries harvest of allocations.
  • Consider species at risk concerns.
comment: Note: also depends on glaciers and groundwater

category: Increase in Hot and Dry Conditions
text1: Possible increase in dry & hot summers
text2:
• Local government wildfire planning required.
  • Summer wildfire response may result in park closures.
  • Possible reduction of recreation services.
  • Industrial/commercial, residential and agriculture demands may exacerbate scarce summer water supplies.
  • Review water management, engage water users, reduce water usage and manage service levels.
  • Consider impact on tourism related to rafting, fishing, recreation at lakes.
  • Update Urban Forestry Management Plan.
  • Wildfires may increase in frequency and intensity.
  • Consider native species heat and drought tolerance.
  • Review management of invasive plants.
  • Consider planting of vegetation that will endure future climatic changes.
  • Consider planting strategically; e.g. riparian zones that may manage or need to endure winter peak flows.
  • Consider tree planting to reduce heat island effects and improve streetscape.
comment: Riparian zone peak flows in a hot and dry spiel? Come on...

text1: Possible shorter snow on ground period
text2:
• Possible shorter winter logging season.
  • Possible decrease in days/weeks of likely work in the woods.
  • Possible increase in log stockpiling needs for mills.

• Alpine, subalpine species range will possibly move up slope.
  • Species will possibly be extirpated at lower elevations.
Consider negative impacts on key industries related to climatic changes, e.g. ski hills.

• Possible disruption of species interactions.
  • Possible change in amount and timing of use of different parts of species' range (eg summer vs. winter areas).
  • Possible increasing invasion by exotic species (also expansion of range of impact of exotic species).
  • Possible changes in populations of pollinators (ripple effect on biodiversity & agriculture).
  • Possible phenological changes.
  • Possible productivity changes.
  • Possible change in behaviour of species.
  • Possible extinction/extirpation and/or hyperabundance.
  • Incidence of human/wildlife conflict may increase.
  • Possible change in winter migration patterns (location, timing); potentially, species will cease migrating.

• Possibility of increased success of pests, increase in range of invasive species.
  • Consider current cultivars and livestock breeds.
  • Production systems may need to be re-evaluated, and alternatives explored.
  • Consider need for monitoring.
  • Consider response/management planning for pests, diseases and weeds.
  • Consider options for improving resilience of agricultural production to pests, diseases, weeds.
Consider how to deal expeditiously with invasive species that are new to an area:
  • Consider impacts of shifting species ranges and migration patterns, and increasing wildlife activity on agricultural crop productivity and quality.
  • Possible increased wildlife activity and changing migration patterns of birds can increase crop damage.

text1: Foliar and stem rusts more likely in pine plantations
text2:
• Select appropriate tree species for planting.
  • Consider planting less pine in these locations.

• Possible forest productivity increase.
  • Potential growth of yield to timber supply.
comment: Does not take into account losses due to drought events, disturbances.

text2:
• May be opportunities for increased productivity.
  • Possible longer production season.
  • Consider new crops and varieties that can be grown.
  • Possible range of southerly crops may expand; but consider effects of potential increased spring rainfall.
